author: Mahesh Bhardwaj
text: Leadership is the process of inspiring, motivating, and guiding others to achieve a shared vision or goal. A leader is someone who:1. Sets direction and vision2. Communicates effectively3. Builds trust and relationships4. Empowers and develops others5. Makes informed decisions6. Takes responsibility and accountability7. Leads by exampleEffective leadership involves:1. Visionary thinking2. Strategic planning3. Collaboration and teamwork4. Adaptability and resilience5. Emotional intelligence6. Authenticity and integrity7. Continuous learning and improvementDifferent leadership styles include:1. Transformational leadership2. Transactional leadership3. Servant leadership4. Autocratic leadership5. Democratic leadership6. Laissez-faire leadershipLeadership is essential in various contexts, such as:1. Business and organizations2. Politics and government3. Education and academia4. Community and social movements5. Sports and teamsGreat leaders inspire and motivate others to achieve their full potential and drive positive change.hashtag#linkedin

author: Harish V Krishnan
text: Leadership may be about influence, but true leadership is about multiplication.Imagine walking into an organization where everyone feels they are merely executing someone else's vision:People follow directions but lack initiativeInnovation happens only at the topTeam members compete rather than collaborateIt's no different for organizations today.Most leaders unintentionally create dependencyMost leaders unconsciously hoard opportunitiesMost leaders unknowingly stifle potentialThe greatest leaders understand they are facilitators of greatness.Here are some transformative leadership practices:The Joy of GivingResearch consistently shows those who give time and resources to help colleagues often achieve the greatest success themselves. As Adam Grant explains in his work, success increasingly depends on how we interact with others.Teaching to LearnWhen you teach, you refine your own knowledge. The act of mentoring forces clarity and mastery, benefiting both the mentor and mentee.Genuine GenerosityKeith Ferrazzi, networking expert, emphasizes that valuable networking comes from genuine generosity. It's about making others successful, which opens doors you never imagined.Leadership LegacyWhen leadership focuses on taking care of those in your charge, it creates a culture where everyone thrives.Your goal as a leader isn't personal status, but collective impact.âœï¸ Your insights can make a difference!â™»ï¸ Share this post if it speaks to you, and follow me for more.

author: Dorit Dor
text: THANK YOU FOR AN UNFORGETTABLE JOURNEY Nearly 30 years ago, I joined a small startup called Check Point Software. We were connecting networks at a time when most of the worldâ€™s networks werenâ€™t connected, offering â€œsecurityâ€ long before it was called cyber.Iâ€™m deeply grateful for the opportunity that Check Pointâ€”and its visionary founders Gil, Shlomo and Marius â€” gave me. What began in R&D expanded into product leadership, business development, M&A, and building new business lines. Over the years, I had the privilege of representing Check Point at the World Economic Forum, in the Cyber Threat Alliance, and across countless stages and forums around the world. My decision to leave comes with mixed emotionsâ€”leaving behind an extraordinary company and team, yet feeling energized by the next chapter. Check Point has always stood for something bigger: making the world a safer place through deep technical innovation and relentless customer focus. We earned the trust of amazing customers and partners, across industries and geographies. What kept me inspired for three decades was the missionâ€”and the people. From employees to customers and partners, Iâ€™ve always made myself accessible, and every direct interactionâ€”every challengeâ€”was a learning moment. Whether it was dealing with adversaries, evolving threats, or emerging technologies, we were constantly anticipating change, realigning strategy, and executing. I always believed that a product isnâ€™t complete when it shipsâ€”itâ€™s only successful when itâ€™s used, delivering real value and hopefully even earning a little love. That belief kept me flying across the world, connecting GTM with product, architecture with customer needs, aligning strategy with execution. It was never about my role or titleâ€”it was about taking full accountability for every aspect of the company. I felt a deep responsibility for each decision, action, and outcome. And none of it would have been possible without being part of the incredible, committed team, every step of the way. Check Point will always be my second family. Iâ€™ll continue supporting the company as an advisor and assisting its success. I am proud to be a Check Point fellow. At the same time, we live in a remarkable (and sometimes crazy) worldâ€”where tech transformation is one of the greatest forces for good. Iâ€™m fortunate to now explore exciting frontiers in cybersecurity, AI, and quantum technology. Each is like a universe of its own, full of opportunityâ€”and I look forward to help bring impact in all three. To everyone whoâ€™s been part of this incredible journeyâ€”customers, partners, colleagues past and presentâ€”thank you. There are too many of you to name, but please know this is a heartfelt, personal thank you. Check Point is, and will always be, a part of me. I trust the team to continue climbing new heights. With love and appreciation,Dorit Important note: The due date of all this is June and by then we will have a more organized goodbyeâ€¦

author: Sean McPheat
text: Want a more engaged team? Stop making these 8 mistakes â¬‡ï¸A disengaged team isnâ€™t lazy - itâ€™s disconnected.If motivation is low, check for these common engagement killers:ğŸš¨ Why Your Team Isnâ€™t EngagedâŒ Lack of Recognition â€“ Feeling undervalued leads to disengagement. A simple "thank you" goes a long way.âŒ Micromanagement â€“ Constant hovering kills trust. Give them space to own tasks.âŒ No Growth Opportunities â€“ Stagnation leads to disengagement. Offer learning and career development.âŒ Unclear Expectations â€“ Vague roles create frustration. Set clear goals.âŒ Poor Communication â€“ Silence breeds confusion. Keep updates transparent.âŒ Overwork and Burnout â€“ Pushing too hard lowers productivity. Balance workloads.âŒ Lack of Purpose â€“ People need to see how their work contributes to a bigger mission.âŒ Toxic Culture â€“ Negativity spreads fast. Create a supportive, respectful environment.âŒ No Autonomy â€“ Powerless employees disengage. Empower them to make decisions.âŒ Disconnected Leaders â€“ Leadership by email isnâ€™t leadership. Be visible and approachable.ğŸ”¥ How to Reignite Engagementâœ… Lead with Curiosity â€“ Ask open-ended questions to understand their challenges and goals.âœ… Celebrate Small Wins â€“ Recognise progress, not just outcomes. Small victories matter.âœ… Create Ownership Moments â€“ Let team members take the lead on tasks.âœ… Personalise Communication â€“ Some need clarity, others need encouragement. Adapt your style.âœ… Gamify the Workplace â€“ Add fun challenges and incentives to boost motivation.âœ… Connect Outside Workâ€“ Build relationships beyond tasks to strengthen trust.ğŸ§  Remember:People donâ€™t just work for pay (although it helps!) They work for purpose, growth, and recognition.How do you keep your team engaged? Let me know in the comments below â¬‡ï¸--------------For more valuable content, follow me, Sean McPheat and then hit the ğŸ”” button to stay updated on my future posts.â™»ï¸ Repost to help more teams stay engaged.ğŸ“„ Download a high-res PDF of this & 250 other infographics at: https://lnkd.in/eWPjAjV7

author: Ole Fredrik Norbye
text: Er du klar for en LinkedIn post som kun formidler forskningskunnskap i tekstformat? AltsÃ¥ - ingen selfie eller karusell. Ingen spÃ¸rsmÃ¥l til leseren eller ingen refleksjoner over at livet er sÃ¥rbart eller at jeg er stolt og ydmyk.  "Zombieledelse" handler er ideer som burde vÃ¦rt dÃ¸de, men som fortsatt gÃ¥r igjen i organisasjonsliv, utdanning og politikk. Ledelse preges nemlig fortsatt av gamle idÃ©er som er feil, men som likevel styrer hvordan vi tenker, ansetter og utvikler ledere. ğŸ§Ÿâ€â™‚ï¸Her er Ã¥tte seigliva myter:1. Ledelse handler om lederenğŸ‘‰ Myten: Lederen er den viktigste, kanskje eneste, drivkraften bak gode resultater.âš ï¸ Problemet: Dette overser kontekst, relasjoner og gruppedynamikk. Det er sjelden Ã©n person alene som skaper suksess. Ledelse er en sosial prosess â€“ ikke en individuell prestasjon.2. Gode ledere er fÃ¸dt sÃ¥nnğŸ‘‰ Myten: Noen har et "lederskapsgÃ©n", og det gjÃ¸r dem naturlig overlegne andre.âš ï¸ Problemet: Dette fremmer elitisme og fratar andre muligheten til Ã¥ utvikle seg. Det stÃ¸tter ideen om at ledelse ikke kan lÃ¦res â€“ noe forskning motbeviser.3. Store ledere gjÃ¸r (alltid) X, Y, ZğŸ‘‰ Myten: Hvis du bare kopierer det "store ledere" gjÃ¸r, blir du selv en god leder.âš ï¸ Problemet: Dette ignorerer at ledelse er kontekstavhengig. Det finnes ingen magisk oppskrift â€“ det som fungerer ett sted, kan feile et annet.4. Vi kjenner en leder nÃ¥r vi ser enğŸ‘‰ Myten: Ledere er lett gjenkjennelige â€“ de ser ut og oppfÃ¸rer seg pÃ¥ en bestemt mÃ¥te.âš ï¸ Problemet: Dette Ã¥pner for skadelige stereotyper. Det favoriserer karismatiske, ofte maskuline personer â€“ og undergraver mangfold.5. Ledelse er det samme overaltğŸ‘‰ Myten: En god leder kan lede hvor som helst, nÃ¥r som helst.âš ï¸ Problemet: Det overser kultur, organisasjonsform og samfunnsmessige forskjeller. Ledelse i et sykehus, en skole eller en startup krever ulike ferdigheter.6. Ledelse er en spesiell ferdighet forbeholdt spesielle folkğŸ‘‰ Myten: Ledere er en slags supermennesker som er hevet over resten.âš ï¸ Problemet: Dette opprettholder maktstrukturer og hindrer deltakelse og kollektivt eierskap. Ledelse bÃ¸r vÃ¦re tilgjengelig â€“ og utvikles â€“ hos mange.7. Ledelse er alltid positivtğŸ‘‰ Myten: SÃ¥ lenge det er "ledelse", er det bra.âš ï¸ Problemet: Denne ideen gjÃ¸r at vi unngÃ¥r Ã¥ stille kritiske spÃ¸rsmÃ¥l om makt, kontroll og undertrykkelse. Ikke all ledelse er god ledelse.8. Folk klarer seg ikke uten ledereğŸ‘‰ Myten: Uten ledere blir det kaos â€“ folk trenger Ã¥ bli styrt.âš ï¸ Problemet: Dette undervurderer menneskers kapasitet til samarbeid, selvledelse og kollektiv intelligens. Mange suksessrike team fungerer best med delt lederskap.For mer om dette, sjekk ut artikkelen: Haslam, S. A., Alvesson, M., & Reicher, S. D. (2024). Zombie leadership: Dead ideas that still walk among us. The Leadership Quarterly, 35(3), 101770.

author: Rajat Sadana
text: "AI is not just a tool; it is a foundational shift in how businesses create value." - Dean Srikant Datar, Harvard Business SchoolğŸ“ğŸ¯This powerful perspective is driving a revolution in business education at Harvard. As someone deeply interested in the intersection of technology and leadership, I'm fascinated by how HBS is fundamentally reimagining what it means to be a business leader in the AI era. What's truly groundbreaking? In 2025, HBS made "Data Science and AI for Leaders" mandatory for all first-year MBA students. This wasn't just adding another tech courseâ€”it signals that AI fluency is now non-negotiable for future business leaders. ğŸ’¡The approach is comprehensive and visionary:â¡ï¸Creating "AI-augmented leaders" who work in partnership with intelligent technologies â¡ï¸Deploying innovative learning tools like AI Tutor Bot and Julius.ai (enabling students to code without prior experience) â¡ï¸Establishing the Digital Data Design Institute (D^3) with partners like JPMorgan Chase, Microsoft, and BCG â¡ï¸Embedding ethical considerations throughoutâ€”not as an afterthought ğŸ“ˆThe results speak for themselves. Over 25% of recent HBS graduates now join tech firms or consultancies focusing on AI strategy, commanding median salaries exceeding $175,000. They're leading AI initiatives at Amazon, McKinsey, and OpenAI. As Professor Karim Lakhani brilliantly puts it: "If the 20th century was defined by the MBA wielding Excel, this century will be defined by MBAs working hand-in-hand with AI agents."This isn't just academic theoryâ€”it's transforming real businesses. When an HBS alumna implemented AI-driven hyper-personalization at DBS Bank, customer engagement increased by 40%. ğŸŒHarvard's commitment extends beyond technical skills to developing leaders with balanced capabilities:â¡ï¸Strategic vision paired with implementation know-howâ¡ï¸Technical fluency alongside ethical judgmentâ¡ï¸Innovation drive with responsible governanceAs AI continues reshaping our business landscape, HBS is ensuring its graduates remain at the forefrontâ€”not just understanding the technology, but actively shaping how it transforms value creation across industries. ğŸ”—Read the article below to find out more!Payal, Gargee, Bhahulya, Kashish, Abha, Rashmi, Dhruv, Bijaya, Iavor Bojinov, Latanya Sweeney, Feng Zhu, e-GMAThashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#BusinessEducation hashtag#Leadership hashtag#HarvardBusinessSchool hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#AIStrategy

author: Tristan Ebel
text: Ma plus grosse erreur de leadership ? Je lâ€™ai faite dÃ¨s le premier jour.Jâ€™Ã©tais fier. FraÃ®chement promu.Je me suis dit : â€œÃ‡a y est, câ€™est mon moment.â€Je croyais que devenir manager, câ€™Ã©tait enfin Ãªtre sous les projecteurs.Jusquâ€™Ã  ce que je comprenneâ€¦Le leadership, ce nâ€™est pas briller.Câ€™est faire briller les autres.Ã€ partir du moment oÃ¹ tu deviens leader, ton impact ne se mesure plus Ã  ce que tu produis.Il se mesure Ã  ce que ton Ã©quipe devient grÃ¢ce Ã  toi.Tes plus grandes victoires ?Ce ne sont plus les tiennes.Ce sont celles que tu rends possibles chez les autres.Le leadership, ce nâ€™est pas :â†’ Avoir toujours le dernier motâ†’ Sâ€™approprier les rÃ©sultats dâ€™un collectifâ†’ Avoir rÃ©ponse Ã  toutCâ€™est tout lâ€™inverse.Câ€™est :â†’ Donner la parole Ã  ceux qui doutent encoreâ†’ CÃ©lÃ©brer les succÃ¨s mÃªme quand ils ne sont pas les tiensâ†’ CrÃ©er un cadre oÃ¹ les talents peuvent Ã©voluerLes grands leaders voient le potentiel avant les rÃ©sultats.Ils te poussent quand tu te retiens.Et te soutiennent quand tu flanches.Tu veux progresser en tant que manager ? author: Peter F. Gallagher
text: Fridayâ€™s Change Reflection Quote - Leadership of ChangeÂ® - Change Leaders Understand Context Before ActingğŸ“Â Leadership Learning!On April 25, 2022, Elon Musk reached an agreement to acquire Twitter for $44 billion. Finalised on October 27, the transaction marked a pivotal moment in the evolution of digital communication and social media governance. Far more than a corporate deal, it exposed the complex intersection of innovation, influence, and ideologyâ€”highlighting the imperative for leaders to understand the environment before initiating bold change.Â Musk, one of the most prominent entrepreneurs of the 21st century, did not simply purchase a platformâ€”he entered the domain of global discourse, with profound implications for expression, ownership, and technological power. Having become Twitterâ€™s largest shareholder earlier that month with a 9.2% stake,Â Muskâ€™s unsolicited offer to buy the company was met with scepticism, reflecting a lack of shared understanding between the proposed change and the broader stakeholder context.Â His public rationale centred on defending free speech and unlocking the platformâ€™s potential by taking it private. The proposal swiftly became a binding agreement, sparking global debates about the influence of billionaires over public dialogue. This acquisition was one of the most controversial in social media history. Never before had a figure with such standing in technology and industry assumed full control of a communications platform so central to global eventsâ€”from the Arab Spring to modern election campaigns. Twitterâ€™s compact format shaped political and cultural discourse; its transfer into Muskâ€™s hands raised urgent questions around neutrality, moderation, and digital integrity. The turbulent road to acquisition underscored the risks of initiating disruptive change without first fully appreciating contextual complexity.Â Muskâ€™s initial investment triggered defensive responses from Twitterâ€™s board, including a shareholder rights plan. Legal disputes emerged when Musk attempted to withdraw over bot account concerns. Twitter sued, and ultimately, the deal closed on October 27. Musk entered Twitter headquarters carrying a sinkâ€”a gesture that became symbolic of sweeping change. Following the acquisition...âœ…Â Change Leadership Lessons:Â Elon Muskâ€™s acquisition of Twitter illustrates how high-stakes decision-making must be grounded in deep contextual understanding to guide bold, strategic transformation.Â Leaders of change must demonstrate strategic persistence when external pressures and legal challenges threaten to derail transformation efforts. They risk causing confusion and instability when acting without a deep understanding of the strategic and organisational landscape in which change will be implemented. Change leaders should prioritise...â€œChange leadership begins with understanding. Acting without context invites unnecessary resistance; however, a new vision aligned with restructuring shapes legacy.â€

author: Dr Lollie Mancey
text: Every single institution has chased performance indicators and KPIs with a fervour that borders on the religious. And in the process, weâ€™ve built systems that prioritise productivity over possibility, measurement over meaning, and replication over imagination.  Itâ€™s not that efficiency is bad. But when speed becomes the dominant value, depth becomes a casualty. From boardrooms to classrooms to policy tables, I see a similar question being whispered behind closed doors:Â Are we heading in the right directionâ€”or just faster in the wrong one?Itâ€™s a question that sits differently with each stakeholder :PolicymakersÂ worry about regulation lagging behind innovation. EducatorsÂ feel pressure to prepare students for jobs that may not exist.CEOsÂ are told to embrace AI while quietly fearing theyâ€™re sleepwalking into ethical minefields.Weâ€™re not lacking intelligence or innovation. What weâ€™re lacking isÂ "consequence literacy" the ability to trace the ripple effects of our decisions, not just across time, but across identity, class, and geography.I often say:Â culture helps you predict the future. But not in the way a trend report does. Culture reveals what weâ€™re willing to tolerate, what we find beautiful, what we exclude, and what weâ€™re quietly rehearsing. Right now, those seeds are asking us to rethink our systems of value.Because whether youâ€™re a founder, a public servant, a parent, or writing policy, the question is no longer:Â Can we build it?Â Itâ€™s:Â Should we? For whom? At what cost?This isn't a manifesto against technology. Quite the opposite. But AI, climate change, bioengineeringâ€”these are not just technical challenges. They are societal reckoning points. And we will not solve them with better tools alone.We needÂ radical cultural intelligence.The kind that sees beyond the dominant worldview. The kind that can hold complexity without collapsing into cynicism. The kind that understands that progress without equity is just innovation for the few, paid for by the many.What would it look like if: CorporatesÂ were measured not just by profit, but by the long-term integrity of their decisions?GovernmentsÂ funded experimentation in ethical infrastructure the way they fund tech parks? UniversitiesÂ stopped preparing students to "fit in" and started preparing them toÂ change the system? Tech foundersÂ had philosophers and poets on their leadership teams as co-designers?I believe in a future where being human together is a design principle, not just a nostalgic ideal. Where rituals, rest, resistance, and imagination are seen as strategic assets. Where the commons are rebuilt, not as a patchwork of policies, but as shared cultural muscle memory.  Make no mistake: the shift from extractive systems to regenerative ones will be messy. It will require grief, humility, and new languages of collaboration. It will need people who can navigate paradox and work across disciplines. It will needÂ us  ... all of us.Impetus. Business Accelerated

text: STUDIJSKO PUTOVANJE U Å ANGAJ Imao sam Äast i privilegiju da budem dio studijskog putovanja u organizaciji Mokrogorska, namijenjenog polaznicima programa Bolji Biznis i MEMBA. Spojili su nas energija, znatiÅ¾elja i Å¾elja za iskustvima.KljuÄna opaÅ¾anja koja nosim sa sobom:ğŸ›¸ U poreÄ‘enju sa evropskim metropolama, Å angaj djeluje kao grad koji je veÄ‡ proÅ¡ao faze razvoja u koje Evropa tek ulazi.ğŸš— ElektriÄna vozila zvaniÄno Äine neÅ¡to viÅ¡e od 50%, u praksi djeluje da ih ima i viÅ¡e. Procesi su znatno manje birokratizovani nego u Evropi.ğŸ¤³ğŸ» Radna snaga je ambiciozna, obrazovana i digitalno pismena. ğŸ¦¾ Dugi radni sati, visok intenzitet i kultura â€uvijek dostupanâ€œ, odudaraju od evropske priÄe balansa privatnog i poslovnog Å¾ivota.ğŸ¤´ğŸ¼ Prisutan je jak fokus na kupca, brzinu i dostupnost.â›©ï¸ Na Zapadu se Äesto Mao smatra tvorcem moderne Kine, ali istinski otac ove Kine je Deng Sjaoping. author: Sumon K.
text: 97% of Resumes Get Rejected within Seconds.But ChatGPT can help you join the top 3%.Here are 8 ChatGPT prompts to create a standout resume:[ ğŸ’¡Tip: Save the post for the future ]--1. Resume summary section"Create a compelling summary section for my resume that encapsulates my professional experience, key skills, and achievements, tailored to a [job position] role at [company] in the [industry] sector, while reflecting the [company culture/value]."--2. Customizing for ATS"Rewrite my resume with keyword optimization to ensure it passes through Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) for a [job position] at [company], aligning with the [key competencies/skills] mentioned in the job description."--3. Cover letter integration"Integrate key points from my resume into a cover letter paragraph that highlights my unique qualifications for the [job position] at [company], emphasizing my [specific skill/experience] that aligns with [company's mission/vision]."--4. Language skills enhancement"Highlight my multilingual abilities in the resume, detailing proficiency levels and how these skills align with [global/market needs] at [company] in the [job position]. Include examples of relevant applications of these skills."--5. Technical skills section"Detail the technical skills, software proficiencies, and certifications that make me a strong candidate for the [job position] at [company]. Tailor the list to focus on tools and technologies emphasized in [industry/role-specific needs]."--6. Soft skills demonstration"Craft impactful examples of how my soft skills, such as [communication, leadership, or teamwork], have driven positive outcomes, tailored for enhancing the soft skills section of my resume for a [job position] at [company]."--7. author: Sadhanaa Giri
text: You are enough. Just as you are.In a world that keeps whispering (and sometimes shouting) that we need to be moreâ€” More polished, more perfect, more filteredâ€” Itâ€™s a quiet act of courage to pause and say: "I am enough."As a coach, I work with people navigating these invisible pressures every day. Women feeling the need to straighten their curls, lighten their skin, smooth every line. Professionals pushing harder just to keep up. Leaders doubting themselves behind carefully curated masks.But confidence doesnâ€™t come from covering up. It comes from showing upâ€”real, messy, honest, human.ğŸŒ¿ This is your reminder: -You donâ€™t need to fix yourself to be worthy. -Youâ€™re allowed to take up space, as you areâ€”today.And if this resonates, letâ€™s connect. Whether youâ€™re a leader, a caregiver, an entrepreneur, or simply someone trying to keep it togetherâ€”Iâ€™d love to walk with you on this journey of reclaiming your wholeness.Follow Sadhanaa Giri for more hashtag#SelfWorth hashtag#AuthenticLeadership hashtag#YouAreEnough LEADerSHIP  DecKâ™»ï¸  Repost if you like the message.Video Credit:  Respective owner

author: Shubham Singh Bais
text: Hereâ€™s a clear, knowledgeable explanation of Teamwork that you can use for any purpose:---Teamwork: A Foundation for SuccessWhat is Teamwork?Teamwork means working together as a group to achieve a common goal. It involves cooperation, communication, and coordination among all members. Each person plays an important role, and their efforts are combined to achieve better results than anyone could alone.---Key Features of Good Teamwork1. Clear hashtag#Communication â€“ Team members openly share ideas, feedback, and information.2. Trust and Respect â€“ Everyone values each other's opinions and skills.3. Shared Goals â€“ All members work toward the same objective.4. Defined Roles â€“ Each person knows their responsibility.5. Supportive hashtag#Environment â€“ Members help, motivate, and uplift each other.---Benefits of TeamworkMore Ideas and Innovation â€“ Different perspectives lead to creative solutions.Improved Efficiency â€“ Tasks are completed faster through cooperation.Better Learning â€“ Team members learn from each otherâ€™s strengths.Greater Motivation â€“ Working together boosts morale and confidence.Strong Relationships â€“ Teamwork builds trust and lasting professional bonds.---Challenges in TeamworkMiscommunicationConflicts or disagreementsUnequal participationLack of coordinationThese can be overcome with good leadership, regular meetings, and mutual understanding.---ConclusionTeamwork is essential in school, the workplace, sports, and daily life. It teaches us how to cooperate, respect others, and achieve goals together. With strong teamwork, we can accomplish much more than we could on our own.---Would you like a short version, a speech, or something for a presentation?hashtag#innovationhashtag#managementhashtag#HumanResourceshashtag#digitalmarketinghashtag#technologyhashtag#creativityhashtag#Futurehashtag#futurismhashtag#Entrepreneurshiphashtag#CareersğŸŒºğŸ’–Follow us for more such knowledge ğŸŒºğŸ¥°

author: Mohammed H. Al Qahtani
text: From Theory to Impact: What Prince Abdulaziz bin Salmanâ€™s Appointment Means for KAUSTâ€™s FutureA royal decree has appointed His Royal Highness Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman as Chairman of the Board of Trustees at KAUST (King Abdullah University of Science and Technology).The headline may be administrative â€” but the real story is strategic.This move signals a deliberate shift: positioning KAUST not just as a research university, but as a national engine for innovation, tightly integrated into Saudi Arabiaâ€™s energy transformation.ğŸ”… Whatâ€™s actually changing?1ï¸âƒ£ A new philosophy of researchKAUST will prioritize not just generating knowledge, but engineering its applications. With leadership from someone shaping national energy policy, research will align directly with industrial needs â€” especially in clean energy.2ï¸âƒ£ A rare intersection of vision and authorityWith the same person setting energy strategy and chairing KAUSTâ€™s board, the gap between â€œwhat we should researchâ€ and â€œwhat we must implementâ€ narrows dramatically â€” a rare advantage in academia.3ï¸âƒ£ Structural access to applied partnershipsPrince Abdulaziz can activate collaborations with projects like:â–ªï¸ NEOMâ€™s green hydrogen initiativeâ–ªï¸ Aramcoâ€™s carbon capture facilitiesâ–ªï¸ Dumat Al Jandalâ€™s wind energy projectNot just as end users, but as live testbeds for scalable innovation.4ï¸âƒ£ A repositioning on the global innovation mapKAUST already has world-class capabilities. Now, it gains strategic velocity â€” moving from a â€œcenter of researchâ€ to a â€œcenter of impactâ€ that drives technical sovereignty and sustainable development through solutions like green hydrogen and carbon capture.ğŸ” This is not just a tribute to a figure â€” itâ€™s a reading of a structural pivot in how national research is operationalized.Strategically, this appointment brings together planning, policy, and execution â€” within KAUSTâ€™s ecosystem.hashtag#KAUSThashtag#Vision2030hashtag#CleanEnergyhashtag#GreenHydrogenhashtag#StrategicInnovationhashtag#ResearchToImpacthashtag#SaudiTransformationhashtag#Sustainability

text: LA DECARBONATION DÃ‰SIRABLEIl y a encore quelques annÃ©es, la dÃ©carbonation industrielle Ã©tait perÃ§ue comme un mal nÃ©cessaire : une obligation rÃ©glementaire de plus, souvent coÃ»teuse, rarement urgente.Mais les lignes bougent.ğŸ‘Aujourdâ€™hui, les PME et ETI industrielles en ont pleinement conscience : 9 dÃ©cideurs sur 10 rÃ©pondent que la dÃ©carbonation est compatible avec leur activitÃ©.Ã€ lâ€™occasion de ChangeNOW  Les Echos  ont dÃ©voilÃ© les rÃ©sultats du sondage OpinionWay  pour Equans  sur le sujet.https://lnkd.in/eb8YGfSfVous comprendrez pourquoi un chiffre a retenu mon attention : prÃ¨s de 60 % des dirigeants identifient la dÃ©carbonation dâ€™abord comme un marqueur dâ€™image, bien plus quâ€™un levier de rentabilitÃ© immÃ©diate.Et pour cause : la dÃ©carbonation est devenue un facteur de diffÃ©renciation, un levier de relation client durable, mais aussi un atout de recrutement au cÅ“ur de la stratÃ©gie de marque.Dans un environnement instable et saturÃ© de discours, la marque devient un repÃ¨re : elle porte un rÃ©cit, incarne une vision, diffuse des valeurs. Câ€™est elle qui crÃ©e de la cohÃ©rence, nourrit la rÃ©putation, renforce la capacitÃ© dâ€™attraction â€” autant pour les clients que pour les talents.Lâ€™engagement climatique, quand il est sincÃ¨re, envoie un signal fort :â€“ aux clients, qui cherchent Ã  aligner leurs achats sur leurs convictions,â€“ aux jeunes talents et aux collaborateurs, en quÃªte de sens,â€“ aux partenaires, qui scrutent la cohÃ©rence des chaÃ®nes de valeur.Dans un tissu industriel oÃ¹ lâ€™offre peut sembler interchangeable, le positionnement bas-carbone devient aussi un marqueur de confiance : il crÃ©dibilise le rÃ©cit, solidifie la rÃ©putation et distingue ceux qui agissent vraiment.Câ€™est une preuve dâ€™engagement, un levier de diffÃ©renciation, un facteur clÃ© de compÃ©titivitÃ©.On ne parle plus seulement de sobriÃ©tÃ© Ã©nergÃ©tique ou dâ€™impÃ©ratif climatique.On parle dâ€™identitÃ© de marque, de culture dâ€™entreprise, de leadership industriel.Ce serait alors la meilleure des nouvelles : cela signifierait que la dÃ©carbonation devient un standard â€” non seulement attendu mais dÃ©sirable.Un levier collectif dâ€™accÃ©lÃ©ration, au service dâ€™un futur alignÃ© sur nos valeurs les plus fortes.PrÃªts ?JÃ©rÃ´me Stubler Pierre Hardouin Richard Dujardin Jean-Philippe Loiseau Ana Giros Mark Dirckx

author: Oliver Ramirez G.
text: These could be quietly draining your teamâ€™s time.(8 common productivity traps & how to solve them)Work inefficiencies can cripple even the best teams:ğŸš© Tasks take longer to perform.ğŸš© Frustrations build up.ğŸš© People begin to stop caring.The worse part about inefficiencies is thatthey often go unnoticed until something big breaks.Here are 8 common traps and how to solve them:1/ Relying on a â€˜Single Expertâ€™ â†³ One person trains everyone on a process â†³ Creates bottlenecks + knowledge gapsğŸ’¡ Document + record to share knowledge2/ No standard way of doing things â†³ Everyone does the same task differently â†³ Leads to delays, rework, confusion ğŸ’¡  Map, benchmark, document, align3/ Manual-heavy onboarding â†³ Shadowing, 1:1s, endless presentations â†³ Eats up senior team timeğŸ’¡ Automate; use onboarding tech4/ Projects keep restarting â†³ Leadership changes direction mid-project â†³ Wastes time + drains moraleğŸ’¡Align on success, get buy-in early5/ Messy work environment â†³ Canâ€™t find docs, assets, info â†³ Teams waste hours hunting for basicsğŸ’¡ Organise, standardise, maintain6/ People accept broken processes â†³ â€œThatâ€™s just how we do itâ€ â†³ Innovation stalls, issues repeatğŸ’¡ Use PDCA to continuously optimise7/ Misaligned team metrics â†³ Teams chase different goals â†³ Creates tension + competing priorities ğŸ’¡ Align everyone to a few core KPIs8/ Underused software tools â†³ Features ignored or disconnected systems â†³ Manual work stays manual  ğŸ’¡ Train, track adoption, integrateYour teamâ€™s productivity is only as strong as the systems you've built.Prioritise removing inefficiencies as you encounter them to set your team for success.Start by auditing and optimising a key process this week.ğŸ’¬ Which inefficiency trap resonated the most?- - -â™»ï¸ Repost to help leaders fight inefficiencies at work. â• Oliver Ramirez G. for leadership & process improvement.

author: Ben Botes
text: Iâ€™ve scaled four companies.And Iâ€™ve made this mistake in every single one.I thought I was scaling a business.But I was really scaling a system that reflectedÂ how I thinkÂ â€” my pace, my blind spots, my unspoken assumptions.What changed everything?A hard look at how I communicate.When strategy falls flat, when teams get misaligned, when growth stallsâ€”itâ€™s not usually the product.Itâ€™s not the market.â†³ Itâ€™s theÂ missing conversations.â†³ The uncomfortable ones.â†³ The overdue ones.â†³ The ones that bring clarity, alignment, and forward motion.ğŸ’¬ Strategic conversationsÂ areÂ the operating system of scale.Because a business canâ€™t grow beyond the quality of the conversations at the top.5 Conversations That Scale:â†³ The Vision ResetÂ â†’ Aligns your team on the next 12 monthsâ†³ The Client FilterÂ â†’ Clarifies who gets your time and energyâ†³ The Value ConversationÂ â†’ Prices based on outcomes, not hoursâ†³ The Ownership Hand-OffÂ â†’ Delegates accountability, not just tasksâ†³ The Momentum LoopÂ â†’ Builds traction through weekly alignmentWant to scale with less friction and more clarity?Start with the next conversation.Inbox me, CONVERSATIONS  and Iâ€™ll send you theÂ Strategic Conversation ChecklistÂ I use with every founder I work with.ğŸ‘‰ Follow Ben Botes for more insights on Leadership, Scale-Ups & Impact Investment.hashtag#FounderLeadership hashtag#ScaleWithClarity hashtag#0Point0001Percent hashtag#StrategicGrowth hashtag#LeadershipThatLasts hashtag#BenBotes

author: Zora Lazarov
text: Some leaders leak. Others lead.Which one are you? ğŸ‘‡Youâ€™re not frustrated because your team is slow.Youâ€™re just:ğŸ‘‰ TiredğŸ‘‰ OverstimulatedğŸ‘‰ Addicted to urgencyğŸ‘‰ And leaking your nervous system all over SlackğŸ§  Neurofact:When your body perceives threat,your amygdala hijacks your perception.So:â€œTheyâ€™re thinkingâ€ looks like â€œTheyâ€™re stalling.â€â€œTheyâ€™re focusedâ€ looks like â€œTheyâ€™re ignoring me.â€And boom, you call it "decisiveness."But your team?They feel reactivity, pressure, and your stress leakingvia bullet points and bandwidth.THE TRUTH:Youâ€™re not surrounded by slowness.Youâ€™re surrounded by people tryingnot to drown in your pace.The 3 Moves for Regulated Leadership1. Audit the Mood You Transmitâ†’ Before you speak, Slack, or delegate...ask:â€œAm I creating clarity or transferring chaos?â€â†’ If you're agitated or rushing? Pause. Donâ€™t project.2. Name the Nervous System, Not the Narrativeâ†’ Instead of â€œTheyâ€™re so slow,â€ try:â€œI feel urgent. Whereâ€™s that coming from?â€â†’ Regulation starts with recognition.3. Build the Pause Inâ†’ One breath. One minute. One circuit-breaker.Not for â€œmindfulness.â€ To get your prefrontal cortex back online.â†’ Thatâ€™s where your real leadership lives.Your urgency isnâ€™t insight.Itâ€™s your biology asking for a break.Not for your team, but for you.ğŸ’¬ Do you agree?ğŸ“® REPOST to those who need this reminder!*******************************************************ğŸ§  Iâ€™m Zora - corporate psychologist & ex-Apple HRğŸ¥ Subscribe to my YouTube (link in my bio)â• Follow for more posts like this.

author: Teharie Naidoo
text: Urgent Vacancy : Regional Manager/Deputy RM : East London - Telecommunications(South African Citizens)* Requires a Degree of Diploma* Please inbox me if you meet the below requirements.(add me as a connection)*PLEASE READ THE ADVERT CAREFULLY BEFORE APPLYING*Purpose of the position:Control of day to day activities of the Regional Network Operations, ensuring optimum performance and expansion of the network continually meeting the needs and expectations of the customer.Provide technical leadership, vision and expertise ensuring staff competencies meet the convergent technological challenges of the futureMajor Responsibilities:Planning and Monitoring- Plan the day to day duties and responsibilities of Radio Network Operations staff, including arrangement of tasks and leave, ect.- Ensure that a routine program (as per the standing procedure) is in place and monitor the performance of these O & M radio routines- Perform an annual assessment of each member of staff as per the company policy, using the above objectives and performance.- Submit reports to designated management, as per requirements.- Prepare the annual budget needs and manage the budget allocations.Ensuring Resources availability and adherence to procedures- Maintain a sound working relationship between the network operations section and all associated parties, within the company and external.- Define objectives for the staff so that management and company objectives are met. Measure the performance, of the staff against those objectives.- Be responsible for the general housekeeping and upkeep of all allocated BTS sites.- Ensure that all staff are applying procedures in their day to day activities, especially regarding all documentation.- Ensure that resources, both material and human are available for all planned network expansions to take place as per schedule.- Improve network availability and quality on a continuous basis.- Ensure that all key performance areas for radio Engineers, Transmission Engineers and OMBs, are met.Hold regular meetings, with staff under your control to manage the sections performance, special projects and communicate any issues from staff to management or vise versa.

author: Aaron Reeves
text: How I find high intent leads in 2 minutes50+ warm leads a week1. Open up salesnavSalesnav is the single best data source for finding leads. But you have to know how to use the filters correctly.2. Set up your personasThis will save you so much time, save the most common people you prospect to. For examle; Above The Line - Sales Leaders (Seniority = Director or CXO or VP) (Function = Sales or Business Development)3. Input your ICPGo onto â€œLead Filtersâ€ then input the info of your ideal customers. The more detailed the better, as this will make your messaging more specififc, add filters like:Headcount, company type, location, industry.4. Toggle on â€œChanged Jobs & Posted on LinkedInâ€New leadership has been brought in for change, they spend 75% of their budget i the first 90 days, so go after them!Reach out and how how you can help them hit THEIR personal KPIs in their new role with your solution.5. Toggle on â€œConnectionâ€ or â€œConnections ofâ€ or â€œPast Colleaguesâ€If you are already connected and know them, you already have established trust so reach out.If you have mutual connections, try and get a warm referral (much higher response rate than cold)If you have worked with them before and know them, use that to your advantage.Look for the warmer leads! Make your life easier.6. Turn on â€œSave searchâ€This way everytime new leads match your criteria youâ€™ll be updated and notified. You can check this every week to have a bunch of great leads to go after.Name it also so you remember what it is.Would you try this workflow?

author: Jermaine Craig
text: We don't have the cash to pay a good salary.We're not purposefully stingy. We're just bootstrapped and building our fund contribution by contribution.That's why I've remained a solo founder (with an EA), handling every aspect of Kwanda, from building the application to impact monitoring, finances, legal, social media, etc.But we're slowly getting to a point where we can pay people, and once we have our non-profit status this year, we'll also try our hand at fundraising.Here's how we'll work around this:We're using a tiered salary structure adjusted per region.Everyone gets paid the same at their level.ğŸ’µ Leadership salaries are $30,000ğŸ’¶ Contributor salaries are $20,000ğŸ’· Entry-level salaries are $10,000.And we'll bump up all the salaries as we grow our capital. We can double those numbers in a year if we get our leadership hires right; they come in and have a tangible impact.For example, a great communications, fundraising, or growth lead can double our income, and this will bubble up to our salaries.Excited to build a model that rewards impact-driven people.Curious to hear what people think of this approach?

author: Jakob Bovin
text: Whatâ€™s the most underrated leadership and management skill today?ğŸ‘‰ Itâ€™s LISTENING.In a world full of noise and constant distraction, weâ€™re gradually losing our ability to truly hear each other.Thatâ€™s why in todayâ€™s environment; the art of listening has become a superpower.But letâ€™s be real - listening well isnâ€™t easy.Here are some of the HIDDEN CHALLENGES that get in the way: - Preconceptions â€“ We filter what we hear through assumptions and biases. That means we often only absorb what we expect to hear. - Emotional reactions â€“ When we feel triggered, our minds race to respond instead of staying open and receptive. - Internal distractions â€“ Our thoughts wander. We rehearse our replies. We drift. - Impatience â€“ We interrupt. We finish othersâ€™ sentences. We focus on what weâ€™ll say next instead of whatâ€™s being said now.ğŸ¯ The good news? LISTENING IS A SKILL. And like any skill, it can be developed.HERE ARE 4 WAYS TO GET BETTER AT IT: - Ask open questions. Try: â€œCan you tell me more?â€ or â€œHow did that feel?â€  These invite real dialogue instead of just quick answers. - Maintain eye contact: It shows presence, signals trust and invites people to open up. - Donâ€™t interrupt: Let the speaker finish. Itâ€™s harder than it soundsâ€”but it changes everything. - Practice active listening: Reflect back what youâ€™ve heard: â€œSo what youâ€™re saying isâ€¦â€  This builds clarity, trust, and connection.ğŸ’¬ What do you think?  Does authentic listening make a difference?Jakobhashtag#leadership hashtag#listening hashtag#communication

author: Chinwendu Nwachukwu
text: The Power of Being the BackboneWhen people talk about business growth, they often highlight the strategies, sales, and leadership. But what about the person who keeps the wheels turning behind the scenes?As an admin support specialist, Iâ€™ve come to realize that efficiency isn't just about doing things it's about doing the right things at the right time.From managing overflowing inboxes to keeping schedules smooth, from organizing documents to ensuring meetings run without a hitch, we are the silent engines behind productivity.If youâ€™ve ever:Forgotten a meeting that magically got rescheduled,Opened your inbox to perfectly drafted follow-ups, orBreathed easier because your day was perfectly planned,Then an admin professional was behind it.We donâ€™t just support, we empower.So, hereâ€™s to all the admin professionals, your work matters, your presence is felt, and your excellence keeps the business alive!Tag an admin professional who keeps everything running like clockwork.Nora Bawa Daniella Ojua Nwanyieze Ikonnie (Growth Partner to CEOs) hashtag#AdministrativeSupport hashtag#VirtualAssistant hashtag#OperationsExcellence hashtag#Efficiency hashtag#WorkSmartâ™»ï¸ Got inspired? Repost to reach more people.Follow Chinwendu Nwachukwu for more!

author: Agata Julia Purzyc
text: Growth needs the right conditions.Like flowers, leaders need support to thrive.Here are 7 key elements for your growth as a leader:1) Clear vision- Define your goals and values- Share your vision with your team- Align everyoneâ€™s efforts with the vision2) Strong mentorship- Seek out mentors who inspire you- Learn from their experiences and advice- Build a network of support and guidance3) Continuous learning- Embrace new skills and knowledge- Attend workshops and training sessions- Read books and articles on leadership4) Constructive feedback- Ask for feedback from peers and mentors- Use feedback to improve your skills- Create a culture of open communication5) Resilience- Learn to bounce back from setbacks- Stay focused on your goals despite challenges- Develop a positive mindset to overcome obstacles6) Empowerment of others- Delegate tasks to build trust and confidence- Encourage your team to take ownership of their work- Celebrate their successes to boost morale7) Self-reflection- Take time to reflect on your experiences- Assess your strengths and areas for growth- Set new goals based on your reflectionsLeadership is more than a title. Itâ€™s about creating the right environment for growth. Invest in yourself and others.And if you need help - I'm here for you.hashtag#LeadershipByAgata

author: Rehan Shaikh
text: It was an absolute pleasure hosting Stella Choe in Pakistan allowing us to showcase the country's role in the future of global business.Over a packed few days in Karachi and Lahore, Stella engaged with some of Pakistan's most dynamic businesses - not just in meeting rooms but also on the ground. She visited factories and facilities that are a testament to the cutting-edge innovation, scale, and global competitiveness of Pakistan's manufacturing sector. The depth of expertise and ingenuity driving this economy forward was evident in every meeting.She also spent valuable time with our teams across functions, exchanging ideas and reinforcing the importance of strong cross-functional collaboration in driving growth for our clients and the Bank. Our differentiator as a trusted partner remains our network strength and the ability to bring together local insight and global perspective as they navigate both market complexity and regional opportunity.Stella's experience, strategic lens and global perspective will be instrumental in helping us accelerate our franchise across key areas - from building stronger client partnerships to expanding sector focus.Thank you Stella for your leadership and confidence in the potential of this market and the people driving it forward.Bill Winters Tanuj Kapilashrami Rola Abu Manneh Arslan Nayeem Saadya Riaz Syed Ejaz Alam Majid Aziz Raeda Latif FCIM Jehangir Adil Qazi

author: Alvin Huang
text: Low performers aren't the problem.You just haven't unlocked their potential.Everyone loves to talk about accountability,But here's the truth most won't admit â¬‡ï¸Performance issues aren't always about the person.Sometimes it's about the environment they're stuck in.Let's imagine an employee - employee X.She showed up with a good attitude.Always listened, tried, stayed consistent - but still underperformed.Then a new leader with real expertise stepped in,And employee X leveled up fast.What changed?Not her. The leadership.Most leaders get this wrong with underperformers...â†’ They keep them around because they're "loyal" or "great for culture."â†’ Or they let them go without asking why they struggled.But a skilled leader CAN turn potential into performance.Here's how:1ï¸âƒ£ Coach with precisionâ†³ Not just feedback, but real development.2ï¸âƒ£ Set crystal-clear standardsâ†³ No vague goals - everyone knows what 'great' looks like.3ï¸âƒ£ Hold people accountable with empathyâ†³ Be both caring and challenging.4ï¸âƒ£ Aligns strengths to rolesâ†³ Right people in the right seats = right outcomes. So before you cut someone loose, ask yourself:âœ… Have they ever had a high-performance manager?âœ… Could better leadership unlock what's missing?If yes, and there's still no progress - make the hard call.But don't confuse a people problem with a leadership failure.Great culture doesnâ€™t mean low standards.And great performance doesnâ€™t mean burning people out.Have you ever seen someone transform under the right manager? â¬‡ï¸â™»ï¸ Repost to help leaders in your network.ğŸ”” Follow Alvin Huang for more content on leadership and people.

author: Gaelle Devins
text: ğŸŒŸ Your Friday FLOW@WORK Spark ğŸŒŸEvery Friday, I share a little inspiration.Hereâ€™s todayâ€™s spark:"The best insights donâ€™t come from reportsâ€”they come from the trenches."Hereâ€™s a reflection from my own journey:Spreadsheets, dashboards, and reports are great tools, but letâ€™s be honestâ€”they only tell part of the story. The real insights? They come from being on the ground, where the action happens.Iâ€™ve learned this firsthand.In all my roles, I always made it a priority to be there with my teams.To listen, observe, and understand what really moved the needle. And the most valuable takeaways? They werenâ€™t in any PowerPoint presentation.They were in the small moments:The morning latte ritualâ€”where a casual chat would reveal game-changing ideas.A shared mealâ€”where real concerns surfaced that never made it into a formal report.Inside jokes about â€œstretchâ€ goalsâ€”which, beyond the laughs, hinted at what truly motivated the team.Being in the trenches taught me that performance isnâ€™t just about numbers, and leadership isnâ€™t just about strategy!It is about connection, curiosity, and stepping away from the desk to see whatâ€™s really happening.Take a moment today to reflect:Whatâ€™s one way you can step into the trenches with your team this week?Share your thoughts in the commentsâ€”Iâ€™d love to hear!Happy Friday, everyone! âœ¨

text: Le dilemme du prisonnier est une expÃ©rience dÃ©finie par le mathÃ©maticien Albert Tucker en 1950.Câ€™est un expÃ©rimentation  sur la confiance : Un policier propose Ã  deux suspects de se dÃ©noncer rÃ©ciproquement:â¡ï¸ celui qui dÃ©nonce lâ€™autre est libre, lâ€™autre prends une peine de prison maximale pour le dÃ©lit  - comme il est considÃ©rÃ© coupable ( par ex. 10 ans) â¡ï¸ si aucun des deux trahi, ils prennent une peine rÃ©duite (le doute) - par exemple 1 anâ¡ï¸ si tous les deux trahissent ils prennent  une peine modÃ©rÃ©e tous les deux, par exemple 5 ans. Cet exemple est utilisÃ© en gÃ©nÃ©ral pour montrer le bÃ©nÃ©fice de la coopÃ©ration, mais il est aussi intÃ©ressant pour illustrer la vertu de faire confiance .Si on ne se fait pas confiance on est tous plutÃ´t perdants.Lâ€™humain a besoin de collaborer pour survivre. author: Fatou Seck Mathon
text: How you lead on Fridays sets the tone for your team.You leave them either empowered or drained for the weekend.These are 4 leadership styles that hurt your team:âŒ The Micromanager Monsterâ†³ Wants updates on everything till the last minute.â†³ Thinks pressure makes diamonds of people.âŒ The Last-Minute Organizerâ†³ Dumps work on the team at 4 PM on Friday.â†³ Creates unnecessary stress and ruins the weekend.âŒ The Weekend Heroâ†³ Sends emails all weekend, unable to let go of control.â†³ Demotivates the team and burns everyone out.âŒ The Endless Criticâ†³ Always ends the week with negative feedback.â†³ Lowers morale and makes the team dread Fridays.Instead, be this leader:âœ… The Friday Resetterâ†³ Clears all pending approvals by noon.â†³ Buffers time for unexpected issues.âœ… The Boundary Setterâ†³ Doesn't drop last-minute surprises.â†³ Models work-life balance by respecting the team's time.âœ… The Celebratorâ†³ Wraps up the week by celebrating wins, big and small.â†³ Ends the day with positivity and encouragement.âœ… The Empowererâ†³ Leaves the team with confidence in their abilities.â†³ Communicates trust and creates a culture of ownership.Your leadership style defines how your team shows up every day.What kind of leader are you on Fridays?Repost to help a friend be a better leader.Follow Fatou Seck Mathon for more.

author: Chris McClellan
text: Feeling the Heat?... ğŸ”¥ It's a common reality for Business Leaders, but burnout doesn't have to be inevitable. Prioritising your well-being isn't a luxury, it's a strategic imperative for long-term success.Here are 3 crucial things Business Leaders should actively do to avoid burnout:1ï¸âƒ£ ğ— ğ—®ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—”ğ—¿ğ˜ ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ˜ğ—²ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—° ğ——ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—´ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»: You hired talented people for a reason. Trust them. Learn to delegate tasks and responsibilities effectively, empowering your team and freeing up your bandwidth for high-level strategic thinking. Trying to do everything yourself is a surefire path to being overwhelmed.2ï¸âƒ£ ğ—¦ğ—°ğ—µğ—²ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—² ğ—¡ğ—¼ğ—»-ğ—¡ğ—²ğ—´ğ—¼ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—² "ğ—¥ğ—²ğ—°ğ—µğ—®ğ—¿ğ—´ğ—²" ğ—§ğ—¶ğ—ºğ—²: Just like you schedule crucial meetings, block out time in your calendar for rest and rejuvenation. This could be anything from a daily walk, a dedicated hour for focused work without interruptions, or a regular weekend completely disconnected from work. Treat this time as sacred; your productivity and creativity will thank you.3ï¸âƒ£ğ—–ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ˜ğ—² ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¦ğ˜‚ğ—½ğ—½ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ˜ ğ—¦ğ˜†ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—²ğ—ºğ˜€: Leadership can sometimes feel isolating. Actively build and nurture strong relationships with mentors, peers, or even a coach. Having a trusted network to share challenges, gain perspective, and receive support is invaluable in navigating the pressures of leadership.Burnout doesn't signal commitment; it signals unsustainability. By prioritising these three areas, you can lead with greater clarity, resilience, and longevity.

author: Lola Bailey
text: The #1 copywriting tip youâ€™ll learn today(ğ˜ğ˜µ ğ˜¥ğ˜³ğ˜¢ğ˜®ğ˜¢ğ˜µğ˜ªğ˜¤ğ˜¢ğ˜­ğ˜­ğ˜º ğ˜ªğ˜®ğ˜±ğ˜³ğ˜°ğ˜·ğ˜¦ğ˜¥ ğ˜®ğ˜º ğ˜¤ğ˜°ğ˜¯ğ˜·ğ˜¦ğ˜³ğ˜´ğ˜ªğ˜°ğ˜¯ğ˜´)I picked it up years ago from a brilliant copywriter called Alan Sultanic.It changed how I write sales copy and, more importantly, how I think about objections.Hereâ€™s the insight:Most of us try to 'overcome' objections in the sales process.Meet them head on.So:- We prepare counterarguments.- Handle them in FAQs.- Script clever rebuttals for sales calls.But what if there was a better way?This is what Alan shared in his ğ˜•ğ˜°ğ˜µğ˜©ğ˜ªğ˜¯ğ˜¨ ğ˜ğ˜¦ğ˜­ğ˜¥ ğ˜‰ğ˜¢ğ˜¤ğ˜¬ Facebook group:Shift your mindset from overcoming objections to addressing resistance.3 Key points:1. Objections arenâ€™t always logical. Theyâ€™re subconscious. They arise when your buyer senses a ğ˜­ğ˜°ğ˜´ğ˜´.Specifically, a trade-off that threatens their sense of safety, time, identity, energy or self-worth.2. Every decision comes with trade-offs.The brain scans for:â€œWhat do I stand to lose if I say yes?â€Thatâ€™s where objections start.And itâ€™s not always obvious.- Buying a weight loss programme might mean losing spontaneity with food.- Joining a mastermind could mean losing time with your family.3. Your job isnâ€™t to argue the logic.Itâ€™s to reframe the loss as a gain.Because every loss comes with a gain, just not always in the form your buyer expects.Examples:â†’Perceived loss: â€œğ˜ğ˜§ ğ˜ ğ˜¨ğ˜¦ğ˜µ ğ˜·ğ˜¶ğ˜­ğ˜¯ğ˜¦ğ˜³ğ˜¢ğ˜£ğ˜­ğ˜¦, ğ˜â€™ğ˜­ğ˜­ ğ˜­ğ˜°ğ˜´ğ˜¦ ğ˜®ğ˜º ğ˜¦ğ˜¥ğ˜¨ğ˜¦ ğ˜°ğ˜³ ğ˜³ğ˜¦ğ˜´ğ˜±ğ˜¦ğ˜¤ğ˜µ.â€â†’Reframe: â€œğ˜™ğ˜¦ğ˜¢ğ˜­ ğ˜´ğ˜µğ˜³ğ˜¦ğ˜¯ğ˜¨ğ˜µğ˜© ğ˜ªğ˜´ ğ˜¢ğ˜£ğ˜°ğ˜¶ğ˜µ ğ˜£ğ˜¦ğ˜ªğ˜¯ğ˜¨ ğ˜¢ğ˜£ğ˜­ğ˜¦ ğ˜µğ˜° ğ˜§ğ˜¢ğ˜¤ğ˜¦ ğ˜¸ğ˜©ğ˜¢ğ˜µâ€™ğ˜´ ğ˜³ğ˜¦ğ˜¢ğ˜­, ğ˜¢ğ˜¯ğ˜¥ ğ˜­ğ˜¦ğ˜¢ğ˜¥ğ˜ªğ˜¯ğ˜¨ ğ˜§ğ˜³ğ˜°ğ˜® ğ˜µğ˜©ğ˜¦ğ˜³ğ˜¦.â€â†’Perceived loss: â€œğ˜â€™ğ˜® ğ˜¯ğ˜°ğ˜µ ğ˜´ğ˜¶ğ˜³ğ˜¦ ğ˜ ğ˜©ğ˜¢ğ˜·ğ˜¦ ğ˜µğ˜©ğ˜¦ ğ˜µğ˜ªğ˜®ğ˜¦.â€â†’Reframe: â€œğ˜›ğ˜©ğ˜¦ ğ˜µğ˜ªğ˜®ğ˜¦ ğ˜ºğ˜°ğ˜¶ â€˜ğ˜´ğ˜±ğ˜¦ğ˜¯ğ˜¥â€™ ğ˜©ğ˜¦ğ˜³ğ˜¦ ğ˜¸ğ˜ªğ˜­ğ˜­ ğ˜´ğ˜¢ğ˜·ğ˜¦ ğ˜ºğ˜°ğ˜¶ ğ˜®ğ˜°ğ˜¯ğ˜µğ˜©ğ˜´ ğ˜°ğ˜§ ğ˜µğ˜³ğ˜ªğ˜¢ğ˜­ ğ˜¢ğ˜¯ğ˜¥ ğ˜¦ğ˜³ğ˜³ğ˜°ğ˜³. ğ˜ ğ˜°ğ˜¶â€™ğ˜­ğ˜­ ğ˜®ğ˜¢ğ˜¬ğ˜¦ ğ˜§ğ˜¢ğ˜´ğ˜µğ˜¦ğ˜³ ğ˜±ğ˜³ğ˜°ğ˜¨ğ˜³ğ˜¦ğ˜´ğ˜´ ğ˜¸ğ˜ªğ˜µğ˜© ğ˜­ğ˜¦ğ˜´ğ˜´ ğ˜°ğ˜·ğ˜¦ğ˜³ğ˜¸ğ˜©ğ˜¦ğ˜­ğ˜®.â€Thatâ€™s the psychology of high-converting copy:You donâ€™t push harder. You remove resistance ğ˜£ğ˜¦ğ˜§ğ˜°ğ˜³ğ˜¦ it builds.Bottom line:If you want to write copy (or hold sales calls) that feel less like convincing and more like clarity, dig deep to uncover the hidden losses behind every buying decision.Then answer them before your buyer ever asks.Thatâ€™s how you create conversions without pressure.___________________Hi, I'mÂ LolaI help learning and development consultants build their thought leadership on LinkedIn and beyond.3 ways I can support you:â¡Done-for-you thought leadership content/personal brandingâ¡Content consultancy/Power Hourâ¡CopywritingCheck out my content strategy playbook:https://lnkd.in/eWUce2Dp

author: Sophie Gourion
text: ÃŠtre manager, câ€™est apprendre Ã  dÃ©cevoir.On ne le dit pas souvent comme Ã§a.Mais câ€™est vrai.On parle de leadership, de posture, de vision.On parle rarement de la solitude feutrÃ©e, de lâ€™ingratitude du rÃ´le, de cette impression tenace de prendre les coups des deux cÃ´tÃ©s.Quand je suis devenue manager, jâ€™ai compris trÃ¨s vite que je ne pourrais plus Ãªtre aimÃ©e de tout le monde.Et que Ã§a allait me coÃ»ter.On ne mâ€™avait pas prÃ©parÃ©e Ã  Ã§a :Ã€ faire redescendre des dÃ©cisions que je nâ€™ai pas prises.Ã€ devoir trancher, expliquer, parfois encaisser pour protÃ©ger.Ã€ courir aprÃ¨s le temps. AprÃ¨s les Ã©quipes. AprÃ¨s le sentiment de bien faire.On dit souvent que le manager est un maillon fort.Mais en rÃ©alitÃ©, il est souvent au milieu, lÃ  oÃ¹ Ã§a coince.Pas vraiment "au-dessus", jamais totalement "avec".Juste dans cette zone floue oÃ¹ lâ€™on attend beaucoup, mais oÃ¹ lâ€™on comprend peu.Et quand on est une femme, il faut en plus composer avec tout le reste :Ce rÃ©flexe de plaire, si profondÃ©ment ancrÃ©.Ce soupÃ§on constant : trop dure, pas assez ferme, trop Ã©motive, pas assez claire.Ce besoin de reconnaissance, parfois confondu avec une faiblesse.Oui, jâ€™ai Ã©tÃ© une people pleaser.Et parfois, je le suis encore.Je le sens quand on parle dans mon dos.Quand je dÃ©Ã§ois.Quand je me remets en question trop fort, trop vite.Jâ€™apprends encore Ã  mâ€™en dÃ©tacher.Ã€ poser des limites sans culpabiliser.Ã€ entendre quâ€™on nâ€™est pas content â€” sans me remettre en question entiÃ¨rement.Ã€ tenir mon rÃ´le, sans me renier.Mais certains jours, oui.Ã‡a fait mal.Et Ã§a ne se voit pas.

author: Neil Bridgeman
text: Hi there LinkedIn friends - I have some news! My time at SINGULART is coming to an end in a couple of months and I am on the look out for my next big role in Marketing and Brand. A special shout out goes to my creative/design/brand partner-in-crime Jay QuirkğŸ—ï¸ A complete product, merchandise & UI overhaul of the customer-facing marketplace resulting in some big shifts in engagement and conversion metricsğŸ¨ A soon-to-launch self-service design system for Performance Marketing to enable the team to run fast and launch new creative iterations on the hop across multiple languages/markets ğŸ¤© Attracting top talent (yes, thatâ€™s you Raphaela Salas Terence Cisse Jay Quirk) into the business - building a lean, but stellar, Product team with world-class creative directionSo with that in mind, what Iâ€™d love in my next role is:ğŸ’« To work in a consumer-facing business that isnâ€™t afraid to take risks and aims to lead the market not followğŸ’« A leadership role that intersects brand, tech, content & creative (with a little bit of product thrown into the mix)ğŸ’« To connect the dots seamlessly between brand and performance marketing ğŸ’« A good olâ€™ fashioned rebrand is also right up my streetğŸ’« UK-centric if possible - permanent preferred but also open to contract If you know of or have any exciting opps on the horizon, Iâ€™d love to have a chat. ğŸ“¸ Oh and hereâ€™s a few pics highlighting some of the things I love outside of work too: mountaineering and adventure; dogs; growing vegetables in my allotment (not necessarily in that order).

author: Shikha Prasad
text: These are NOT real Scrum Master interview questions:- "What is Agile?"- "Define Scrum"- "What's a sprint?"- "List the Scrum events"- "What's your certification?"- "How do you run a daily stand-up?"- "What's the difference between Agile and Scrum?"- "Explain the Scrum roles"Today, these are just SURFACE-LEVEL questions.Companies expect more â€” it's not textbook definitions or buzzwords they're after.In fact, asking only these things can actually do more harm than good.It can make candidates wonder if you truly understand what makes a great Scrum Master.Modern organizations are looking for something else. They want to know:- How you REMOVE IMPEDIMENTS others don't even see?- How you COACH teams through conflict and uncertainty?- How you TRANSFORM team dynamics without asserting authority?- How you MEASURE success beyond velocity and burndown charts?- How you BUILD TRUST with skeptical developers and product owners?- How you BALANCE servant leadership with uncomfortable accountability?In a time of rapid digital transformationInterview questions shouldn't be seen as "checkbox items"They should be seen as WINDOWS.Windows into how candidates actually think and operate in the real world.â™»ï¸ Found this helpful? Share with your networkAnd follow for more content on building high-performing Agile teams!

author: Enock Yeboah-Mensah CA,Mphil
text: ğŸ§  hashtag#Disruptive hashtag#Leadership Isnâ€™t Just Bold â€” Itâ€™s Brave Enough to Listen. At Apogee Bank, the silence after a single cost-cutting decision spoke louder than any financial report.hashtag#Productivity dropped. hashtag#Resignations climbed. And hashtag#trust? It quietly evaporated.But this wasnâ€™t a story about policy failure â€” it was about the failure to speak up. Theorhema, the CEO, didnâ€™t just face a numbers problem. He faced a cultural one: a boardroom so gripped by fear, candor became collateral damage. Until one moment of reckoning changed everything.âœ¨ â€œhashtag#Speak hashtag#truth to hashtag#powerâ€ became the new unspoken line at the top of every C-Suite job description. âœ¨ hashtag#Psychological hashtag#safety was no longer a buzzword; it became the bedrock of revival. âœ¨ hashtag#Candor was no longer seen as resistance â€” it was leadership.The real shift? Understanding that silence isnâ€™t neutral. In leadership, it can look like hashtag#loyalty, but it often acts like sabotage.ğŸ”Š Letâ€™s hashtag#build hashtag#cultures where the bravest thing isnâ€™t making a decision, but challenging one. Because the strongest teams arenâ€™t built on agreement. Theyâ€™re built on hashtag#trust, hashtag#candor, and hashtag#courage.hashtag#Leadership hashtag#PsychologicalSafety hashtag#ExecutiveLeadership hashtag#CultureMatters hashtag#DisruptiveLeadership hashtag#CourageAtTheTop hashtag#TrustIsStrategy hashtag#SilentSabotage hashtag#SpeakUpCulture hashtag#FutureOfWork

author: Giovanni Beggiato
text: Your title says â€œManagerâ€The team, is still looking for one.Your team doesnâ€™t feel led.They feel watched.They feel managed.They feel... tired.You talk about "empowering others", while they stay silent in meetings.You preach "ownership", while theyâ€™re afraid to take a step without permission.You say "people-first", but theyâ€™ve stopped believing it long ago.A title doesnâ€™t make you a leader.Your actions do.And right now? The group chat is talking about you.If you wanna change the narrative, do this:- Start listening more than you speak. - Start asking what they need, not just whatâ€™s next. - Start showing up in the chaos, not just for the credit.You are their Manager, so act like one.They need you.They care about you.They want to support you.Your best people will leave, if you don't become a leader.â™»ï¸ Repost to back real leadership, not just titles.ï¼‹ Follow Giovanni Beggiato for insights on AI and career.

author: Anna Bertoldini
text: Employee-generated content is the next frontier of brand storytelling.This morning, I listened to a fantastic BBC News Business Daily podcast episode, "Meet the workfluencers" on the rise of employee advocacy. (will link in the comments)The episode covers this topic from many angles, but my takeaway?Forget polished influencer campaigns, todayâ€™s audience craves something real.They want to see what itâ€™s like behind the scenes.They want to feel your company culture.They want to trust the humans behind the brand.And guess what?The most credible storytellers arenâ€™t hired influencers.Theyâ€™re your own employees.Whether itâ€™s a TikTok from a Chipotle Mexican Grill team member learning the ropes or an Anthropologie stylist sharing their top gift picks, employee-generated content (or EGC) is shaping the future of marketing, sales, and recruitment.This is something we're actively fostering and encouraging at NielsenIQ with our employee and leadership advocacy programs. Humans sell, recruit, and represent much better than companies. Why?Because they're authentic.Because they're relatable.Because people trust faces. In 2025, employee voices will be louder, and more influential, than ever.It's a win-win for enhancing their own personal brands and the brands they work for. What do you think?

author: Madhu Murty
text: The Leadership Crisis We Donâ€™t Talk About EnoughNot every leadership failure is loud. Some slip in quietly â€” unnoticed, unchallenged, and unresolved.One of the most common? - Avoidance.We avoid tough conversations, delay a decision everyoneâ€™s waiting on, ignore a pattern thatâ€™s draining the team, and hope a problem will fix itself when we know it wonâ€™t. We think weâ€™re being diplomatic, but avoidance isnâ€™t kindness. Itâ€™sÂ costly silence.Every leader has faced it. I have, too. But if we donâ€™t address what we avoid, it spreads. It affects culture, performance, and trust.This article includes real-life anecdotes, deep reflection, and a call to courageous action.I hope it resonates with leaders, managers, and anyone trying to build something lasting. Leadership isnâ€™t just about what we face; itâ€™s about what we refuse to postpone.Read, like, and share the article:hashtag#Leadership hashtag#PeopleCulture hashtag#OrganizationalHealth hashtag#ManagerEffectiveness hashtag#LeadershipDevelopment hashtag#QualiZeal hashtag#MadhuMurtyRonanki

author: Christophe Fouquet
text: A year ago, I stepped into the role of ASMLâ€™s CEO. I wanted to take a moment today to reflect on the past year.â–¶ What continues to surprise me after so many years at ASMLThe semiconductor industryâ€™s innovative power and its potential to revolutionize society. The latest example is of course Artificial Intelligence. Weâ€™ve just celebrated the 60th anniversary of Mooreâ€™s law, our shared pursuit of faster, smaller, cheaper and more energy-efficient chips. Mooreâ€™s law and the partnership between the key industry players to realize it remain the foundation of our innovation and the positive impact we can have on society.â–¶ What I have learnedThe model that we have relied on for many years, the model of global and open collaboration, is being challenged. Our industry is seen as strategic and of national interest, which brings with it new restrictions and possibly even a decoupling of different regions. We can lament and long for the good old days, but the truth is that we need to adapt to the new situation. This is a key leadership challenge â€“ for me personally and for the ASML leadership, but also for business leaders and policy makers in general. It is absolutely critical that our home base, Europe, steps up to the challenge. On a personal note, this past year has reminded me how much I can learn by listening to our people and all our stakeholders â€“ and the positive impact it has when we act on their input.â–¶ What I am grateful forAll the support from the ASML team, our customers and other key stakeholders. You couldnâ€™t wish for more when stepping into such a role. Iâ€™m immensely proud of hashtag#TeamASML, our people and their exceptional talents, their endless creativity and ideas to support the industry for the next decade and beyond.

author: Abhisake Dutta
text: People donâ€™t quit companies. They quit a broken system. I once asked a colleague why they were leaving a job they were great at.Their answer? â€œIâ€™m tired of feeling unnoticed.â€The real reasons behind resignations:1. toxic culture. - The air people breathe at work matters.2. poor leadership. - Micromanagement and favoritism kill morale faster than bad pay.3. zero career growth. - Stagnation is the quickest path to disengagement.4. lack of control. - People want agency over their work, not endless red tape.5. unfair treatment. - Respect and equity are non-negotiable for todayâ€™s workforce.6. low recognition. - A simple â€œthank youâ€ goes a long way.7. poor compensation. - Money isnâ€™t everything, but itâ€™s not nothing either.What leaders can do instead:1) ask your people whatâ€™s not working. - Transparency starts with a conversation.2) act on feedback, quickly. - Listening without action is worse than silence.3) invest in career growth. - Build ladders, not walls, for your employees.Itâ€™s not about rebuilding your workforce from scratch.Itâ€™s about creating a system where people want to stay.Have a wonderful day â™»ï¸.â™»ï¸ Repost this to your network if you found it insightful!Follow for more such posts.hashtag#employee hashtag#advice hashtag#tips hashtag#workplace hashtag#workculture hashtag#leadership hashtag#toxicity

author: Sorina Manu
text: Hey LinkedIn, letâ€™s talk ''free value''.Youâ€™ve heard the mantra:Be generous.Give.Teach.Share.But letâ€™s not pretend thereâ€™s no second voice.The one that whispers:â€œTell them whatâ€”but not how.â€â€œGive, but not too much.â€â€œSave the real stuff for paying clients.â€Thatâ€™s not generosity.Thatâ€™s performance.Thatâ€™s gatekeeping, polished up.So hereâ€™s the real question:When you give, what space are you in?Generosity rooted in fear isnâ€™t generosity.Itâ€™s self-protection.Scarcity.Energetic leakage.â€œTheyâ€™ll copy me.â€â€œTheyâ€™ll take and never pay.â€â€œIf I give too much, Iâ€™ll lose my edge.â€But hereâ€™s the truth:From wholeness, giving becomes power.You calibrate your field.You create resonance.You reveal who you are.And your people feel it.Theyâ€™re not chasing freebies.Theyâ€™re listening for:âŸ¶ TruthâŸ¶ EmbodimentâŸ¶ CongruenceAnd when they feel it, they invest.Not because you held back.Because you gave something real.Because they trust your clarity.Your energy.Your leadership.You donâ€™t lose by giving.You lose by withholding.By filtering.By shrinking into â€œsafe.â€This is your reminder:Teach like your legacy depends on it.Because it does.P.S. author: Andrew Constable, MBA, BSMP, XPP
text: Making strategy behind closed doors is a prescription for failure.For years, the traditional approach looked like this: The executive team locks itself in a boardroom. They go away on retreat. They come back with a fully formed strategy.But hereâ€™s the problem: That method breeds siloed thinking. It limits diverse input. And it disconnects strategy from execution.What happens when strategy is created in isolation?â˜‘ It misses operational realities. â˜‘ It lacks buy-in from the people who execute it. â˜‘ It reinforces outdated, top-down leadership models.The fix?1. Involve cross-functional voices in strategic planning. 2. Treat strategy as a living conversation, not a one-time event. 3. Use transparency to build alignment and ownership.The more open your strategy process, the more resilient your outcomes.Because the best ideas donâ€™t always come from the boardroomâ€”they come from the people living the business daily.P.S. If you like content like this, please follow me.

text: Who said coaches couldn't invest in sports teams too? ğŸ€âš½Okay yesâ€”he is a former athlete.And not just any athlete.In December 2024, The Friedkin Group, through the entity Roundhouse Capital Holdings, acquired Everton Football Club from Farhad Moshiriâ€™s Blue Heaven Holdings. ğŸ”µâšªThis week, they announced that National Basketball Association (NBA) Hall of Famer and Dallas Mavericks Head Coach Jason Kidd was joining the ownership group.ğŸ† 10-time NBA All-Star and 2011 NBA Champion (with the Mavericks)ğŸ¥‡ Olympic gold medals in 2000 & 2008ğŸ§  Coaching stints with the Brooklyn Nets, Milwaukee Bucks Inc. & Dallas MavericksWhy?Well, Everton Executive Chairman Marc Watts put it best:â€œğ´ğ‘  ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘’ ğ‘œğ‘“ ğ‘¡â„ğ‘’ ğ‘ğµğ´â€™ğ‘  ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘  ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘ ğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘¤ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘¢ğ‘™ ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘â„, â„ğ‘–ğ‘  ğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘¤ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘’ ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘ ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘” ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¦ ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘™ ğ‘ğ‘’ ğ‘ğ‘› ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘’ ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘’ ğ‘“ğ‘œğ‘Ÿ ğ¸ğ‘£ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘›. [â€¦] ğ»ğ‘’ ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘™ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘” ğ‘ ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿ ğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘” ğ‘œğ‘“ â„ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘“ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘’ ğ‘ğ‘  ğ‘¤ğ‘’ ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘¦ ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘’ ğ‘¡ğ‘œ ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿ ğ‘“ğ‘¢ğ‘¡ğ‘¢ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ ğ‘“ğ‘œğ‘Ÿ ğ‘¡â„ğ‘–ğ‘  ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘’ğ‘‘ ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘¢ğ‘.â€Also joining Roundhouse is Christopher Sarofim, Chairman of Fayez Sarofim & Co., bringing nearly 40 years of investment and fund management experience.I firmly believe that sitting alone on a cap table isnâ€™t a sign of strengthâ€”it show weakness.True strength lies in surrounding yourself with a diverse range of perspectives and expertiseâ€”just as the Friedkins are wisely doing with Everton.Â ğŸ‘Other US athlete investors across English football:ğŸ€ LeBron James â€“ Liverpool Football Club (through Fenway Sports Group)ğŸˆ JJ Watt â€“ Burnley Football ClubğŸˆ Tom Brady â€“ Birmingham City FC â›³ Jordan Spieth & Justin Thomas â€“ Leeds United (through San Francisco 49ers' 49ers Enterprises)The Friedkins are also putting smart leadership moves are in motion:Angus Kinnear joining as CEO from June 2025 (ex-Leeds, Arsenal, West Ham).Simon Hunter joining as Chief Stadium Commercial Officer (ex-Chelsea) as part of the move into their new 52,888-capacity stadium.Aaron Duckmanton joining as Chief Marketing & Digital Officer (ex-Leeds, Crystal Palace).ğŸ”´âšª Meanwhile in France, AS Cannes (acquired by The Friedkin Group in June 2023) is having a standout season: French Cup semi-finalists & sitting 2nd in the league, with major infrastructure plans led by the great FÃ©licien LABORDE.Kudos to the Friedkins for the incredible work theyâ€™re doing to positively transform European football.â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ğŸ‘‰ Follow me for (hopefully valuable) insights on sports investing, and check out Achille de Rauglaudre to tap into our Expert Network for strategic, financial, and operational advisory across the sports ecosystem.

text: What if Canada, Japan, the EU, and China decided they were done funding Americaâ€™s dominance?Thatâ€™s not a movie script. author: Ajay Kelkar
text: "Donâ€™t fight the hill," he said. I was halfway up Peddar Road during a half-marathon, legs burning, breath short. That one lineâ€”uttered quietly by a strangerâ€”has stayed with me through runs, reviews, even relationships.In this monthâ€™s edition of the Leadership Change Lab, I explore something most of us avoid: discomfort.But Iâ€™m learning it isnâ€™t one thing. Thereâ€™s the discomfort of being overloaded. Of not belonging. Of repeating old habits. Of hearing something gentle, but true.In this piece, I return to a moment at Cequityâ€”a project, a teammate, and a senior leader who held up a quiet mirror. I revisit a friendâ€™s comment, one that landed harder than any formal feedback. And I reflect on how our body often knows before we doâ€”tight shoulders, fast talk, a skipped breath.ğŸ“I name four discomfort zones Iâ€™ve lived through. ğŸ“I share how coachability shows upâ€”not in theory, but in meetings, meals, and mid-run thoughts. ğŸ“And I ask: What if growth doesnâ€™t come from fixing thingsâ€”but from staying with what feels difficult, just a little longer?This is not a â€œhow to.â€ Itâ€™s a â€œwhere I am.â€ If youâ€™ve felt stuck, reactive, or just a little off-rhythm lately, maybe this will meet you where you are too.Read Part 4 here hashtag#LeadershipLab hashtag#Coachability hashtag#LeadershipInPractice

ÙˆØ£Ù†Ø§ ÙØ®ÙˆØ± Ø¨Ø§Ù†ØªÙ…Ø§Ø¦ÙŠ Ø¥Ù„Ù‰ Ù…Ø¤Ø³Ø³Ø© ØªÙ‚Ø¯Ø± Ø§Ù„Ø§Ø¨ØªÙƒØ§Ø±ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù…Ø³Ø¤ÙˆÙ„ÙŠØ© Ø§Ù„Ø¨ÙŠØ¦ÙŠØ©ØŒ ÙˆØ§Ù„ØªÙ…ÙŠØ² Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‡Ù†ÙŠ.ÙƒÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø´ÙƒØ± ÙˆØ§Ù„ØªÙ‚Ø¯ÙŠØ± Ù„Ø²Ù…Ù„Ø§Ø¦ÙŠØŒ ÙˆÙ…Ø±Ø´Ø¯ÙŠÙ‘ØŒ ÙˆÙ‚ÙŠØ§Ø¯Ø© Ù‡ÙŠØ¦Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø¨ÙŠØ¦Ø© â€“ Ø£Ø¨ÙˆØ¸Ø¨ÙŠØŒ Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¯Ø¹Ù…Ù‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù…ØªÙˆØ§ØµÙ„ØŒ ÙˆØ­Ø±ØµÙ‡Ù… Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø§Ø¦Ù… Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø¨Ù†Ø§Ø¡ Ø¨ÙŠØ¦Ø© Ø¹Ù…Ù„ ØªØ­ØªÙÙŠ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø¯ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ø¬ØªÙ‡Ø§Ø¯.ÙˆØ¥Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø²ÙŠØ¯ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø·Ø§Ø¡ ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø¥Ù†Ø¬Ø§Ø²Ø§Øª ÙÙŠ Ù…Ø³ÙŠØ±ØªÙ†Ø§ Ù†Ø­Ùˆ Ù…Ø³ØªÙ‚Ø¨Ù„ Ø£ÙƒØ«Ø± Ø§Ø³ØªØ¯Ø§Ù…Ø©.I am deeply honoured and humbled to receive the Golden Award as part of the 10th Cycle of the Al Dana Award at the Environment Agency â€“ Abu Dhabi.This recognition is more than just a personal achievement it is a reflection of the dedication, persistence, and commitment that has been poured into years of work focused on sustainability, environmental stewardship, and impactful change.Winning this award reinforces that the efforts invested through challenges, growth, and continuous learning are not only being seen but are also making a difference. I am proud to be part of an organisation that values innovation, environmental responsibility, and professional excellence.A heartfelt thank you to my colleagues, mentors, and the leadership at Environment Agency â€“ Abu Dhabi for their unwavering support and for creating a culture where hard work is both nurtured and celebrated.Hereâ€™s to continuing the journey toward a greener, more sustainable future together.hashtag#AlDanaAward hashtag#GoldenAward hashtag#EnvironmentAgencyAbuDhabi hashtag#Sustainability hashtag#Recognition hashtag#Gratitude hashtag#ProfessionalMilestone

author: Flora Castillon
text: 3 public speaking mistakes smart women make (and how to fix them): 1ï¸âƒ£ Waiting to feel ready.âœ You think youâ€™ll speak up when you finally feel confident.But confidence doesnâ€™t come first.It comes from creating the belief that you are safe, worthy, and allowed to be heardand then doing it while youâ€™re still nervous.2. Over-preparing.âœ You memorise every word. You rehearse 20 times.But when your body isnâ€™t regulated, even perfect prep wonâ€™t protect you.You lose connectionâ€”and it shows.Share your message, your voice, your convictions, not your script.3. Trying to be liked instead of being clear.âœ You soften your tone to be â€œnice.â€You apologise when you stumble on a word.But all that does?Dilutes your messageâ€”and your authority.If you want to speak powerfully,you need to connect.________________________________________________________âœ Iâ€™m an ex-corporate leader, motivational and leadership speakerâ†’ backed by the therapeutic power of working with your deepest subconscious fears.â†³ I help women rewire the fear behind the freezeâ™¡ connect with their audienceâœ– and take pleasure in being seen and heard.DM me â€œSPEAKâ€ to start.

author: Elangovan Perumal, PMPÂ®
text: This stat stopped me in my tracks:75% of teams do better under inclusive leaders.Not slightly better.A lot better.But here's the part most people miss:Itâ€™s not about diversity quotas.Itâ€™s not about being politically correct.Itâ€™s about how people feel when they walk into work.Iâ€™ve seen both sides.Iâ€™ve been on teams where I had to shrink myself to fit in.Where speaking up felt risky.Where different perspectives were treated like threats, not strengths.And Iâ€™ve been on teams where I felt seen.Heard.Safe.Led by someone who didnâ€™t just tolerate differences â€” but welcomed them.Made space for them.Built trust on purpose.Thatâ€™s when the work got better.----ğŸ“Œ Subscribe to my FREE Newsletter, LEVEL5 INSIGHTS: [https://shorturl.at/FWqFN] Follow Elangovan for leadership and personal growth insights."Repost" this with your network to inspire others to lead with purpose
